entry.heading: Lead and copper casting
entry.block: Lead and tin come out well in white chalk but the softer it is the better. That from Champagne wins first prize, and it is transported to Lyon. Burnt and calcinated horse bones cast very neatly.
I believe that the marrow from the horns of oxen or sheep, that is to say, the spongy bone from inside, casts quite neatly and is better than bone.
Note that any sour metal comes out better than a fat one. Also, lean sand receives it and absorbs it better than dense sand.
